Award.AwardTitle: Degenerate Partial Differential Equations in Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Degenerate partial differential equations arise naturally in many subjects in mathematics, physics and engineering. However, the theory for degenerate partial differential equations is not well developed due to the complexity of the degeneracy. It is a common phenomenon that degeneracy causes a loss of derivatives for solutions. One of the central tasks is to identify optimal conditions under which classical solutions exist and possess nice properties. Such a task is reflected in all proposed problems. Our goal is to search for techniques to establish a priori estimates for perspective solutions under these optimal conditions. Breakthrough in this direction will have broad impacts to the whole field of degenerate partial differential equations and their applications.

The investigator will carry out several research projects studying degenerate differential equations from Riemannian and complex geometry and general relativity. These include the study of Abreu's equations and extremal metrics on toric varieties, study of the generalized Jang equation and the Penrose inequality, investigation of the isometric embedding of closed surfaces in the 3-dimensional Euclidean space, and investigation of boundary behavior of minimal surfaces in the hyperbolic space. The main objectives are to understand the impact of the degeneracy on properties of solutions and to investigate the behavior of solutions near the sets of degeneracy. The discussion of the proposed mathematical problems will improve our understanding of more complicated degenerate partial differential equations in various applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Partial differential equation is an important subject in mathematics. The fundamental problem is the study of the existence and properties of solutions. The development of partial differential equations has influenced the development of other fields such as Riemannian and complex geometry and general relativity. The PI's research has been greatly influenced by problems and techniques in Riemannian geometry. The study of partial differential equations in a geometric setting has provided interesting new questions with fresh insight to old problems. The problems addressed in this award involve partial differential equations of various types, elliptic, hyperbolic and of mixed type, and in particular, degenerate or singular partial differential equations. Some problems have close connections with other fields in mathematics, including complex geometry and general relativity. Due to the complexity of the degeneracy and singularity, there has been no general theory for degenerate or singular partial differential equations. The problems proposed and studied in this award are related to some important classes of degenerate partial differential equations. Their solution advances our knowledge in all the aforementioned areas. 

Broader Impacts: The proposed work will have broader impacts in several aspects. First, degenerate partial differential equations arise naturally in many subjects in mathematics, physics and engineering. The discussion of the proposed mathematical problems will improve our understanding of more complicated partial differential equations in various applications. Second, through the proposed research, the PI actively participates in and contributes to the undergraduate and graduate program at Notre Dame. The PI is advising three graduate students. He is also active in organizing mini-courses, workshops, and conferences, and in delivering lectures to graduate students and researchers. Third, the PI interacts with mathematicians from many different research areas and from many parts of the world. Such interdisciplinary and international approach brings new perspective and greater depth to each field. Many of his collaborators are junior researchers. Fourth, the PI is engaged in the development of a textbook on degenerate partial differential equations. His goal is to make this interesting topic more accessible to a wide range of researchers in many disciplines.
